advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.atarihq.com/tsr/">ITSR'S NES ARCHIVE</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (OCT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first 1982 U.S. Advert.<br><br> Advert said <br><br>THE COMMODORE 64 COULD BE THE MICROCOMPUTER INDUSTRY'S OUTSTANDING NEW PRODUCT INTRODUCTION SINCE THE BIRTH OF THIS INDUSTRY. (Shearson / American Express) <br><br><font color="#666666"> The value of a computer is determined by what it can do. What it can do is largely determined by its memory.<br> The Commodore 64's basic RAM is 64K. This amount of power is unusual in a micro at any price.<br> At $595 it is astonishing.<br> Compared with an Apple II+, for instance, the Commodore 64 offers 33% more power and considerably les than 50% of the cost.<br> Compared with anything else, it's even more impressive...<br><br> If you've been waiting for the "computer revolution", consider it as having arrived... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Adopt a little gifted"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGA POSTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert was for the Serie 5 and the ACS-8000 systems.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert shows: <br><br> - the <b>WH89</b> computer ($2295)<br> - the <b>WH11A</b> 16-bit computer, DEC PDP 11/03 compatible ($1895)<br> - the <b>WH19</b> video terminal ($995)<br> - the <b>WH26</b> dual floppy disc system ($2595)<br> - the <b>WH14</b> serial printer ($895)<br><br> To note: in 1979, the company name was <b>Heath Schlumberger data systems.</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BYTE SHOPPER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Spring 1978 issue of Byte shopper guide</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TEI BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> For years, people have been trying to build a better Apple II.<br> It finally happened.<br> Meet the Apple IIe, an impressive new version of a most impressive machine.<br> The 'e' means enhanced. Which means a bundle of new features...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NLS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert from Non-Linear Systems, dated July, 1982 for the KAYCOMP II that was not still called KAYPRO. <br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"><b>A WORD ABOUT NLS</b><br> Non-Linear Systems, inc. is the originator of the digital voltmeter and an innovative leader in the field of electronic test equipment.<br> Organized in 1952, NLS has been a major supplier of digital voltmeters and ratiometers to large corporations in the aerospace industry. Since 1972, NLS has been consumer directed, providing small, portable multimeters, oscilloscopes, counters, frequency meters, temperature meters. And now, NLS has entered the world of computers with one though - to provide the best value in a small, business, scientific and family computer.</font><br><br> Standard software delivered with the KAYCOMP II: <br><br> - <b>CP/M 2.2</b> - operating system<br> - <b>S/BASIC</b> - Structured Basic compiler<br> - <b>PROFIT PLAN</b> - Electronic worksheet<br> - <b>SELECT</b> - Complete word processing system<br> - <b>TEACH</b> - A self-teaching guide to SELECT </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> A computer that, for the first time, works with you rather than just for you. Hardware and Software co-ordinating perfectly, Apricot arrives complete and ready to work.<br> The MicroScreen on the keyboard, unique to Apricot, performs a variety of practical functions as a calculator, calendar, time display, and as a window on the screen. Most signifIcantly the MicroScreen prompts and assists the user by presenting simple options whilst running applications.<br> Incorporating the very latest advances in computer technology, Apricot uses 31/2" pocket-size diskettes. Secure and compact, yet offering increased storage capacity.<br> As you'd expect with a 4th generation system, Apricot offers true 16-bit processing, multi-processor architecture and 256k RAM as standard. <br><br> With Pulsar 16-bit business software and compatibility with the best selling ACT Sirius 1 and IBM PC, Apricot already has the largest available software library. <br><br> Apricot includes over £750 of software­ - SuperCalc spreadsheet, business and communications software - to ensure that your system is immediately effective. And because executives are not office bound, Apricot offers portability, a further feature aimed at improving efficiency.<br> Powerful sleek and sophisticated and all at an amazing 4th generation price.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the competition is dumb !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Quite impressive, non ?!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/"><img src="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/ban_pc1s.gif" border="0"></a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://mayura.jp/blog" target="_blank">Mayura Labo</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983 - The real-size system picture occupied almost the full right page. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"List your technical requirements, Hewlett-Packard is ready to answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's new. It's the Hit-Bit" <br><br> "The computer according to Sony"</blockquote>

computer.description:
Extremely rare french portable computer!
Sobrelec was based in Bretagne, near Brest (France). It was founded by Marcel Richard, former Thomson engineer, in 1974. They used to produce goods for Thomson or Marine Nationale (french Navy). They also produced the LX-500 and LX-525 computers for Logabax.
At the Sicob 1982 exhibition they presented their first own computer : the Totus. It is luggable system, quite similar to the Osborn 1, with a bigger screen though, and two 370 KB 5.25'' built-in disk drives.
Apparently it was mainly used by accountants in Bretagne, while moving from farms to farms.
computer.name: Totus
